name: Official Website
description: The official website for the Qt framework.

name: Qt Documentation
description: Official Qt documentation.  Massive and comprehensive.

name: Qt Newsletters
description: The best of Qt, straight to your spam filter.

name: Qt Bug Tracker
description: If you think you've found a bug with Qt or one of its related projects, report it here (or see if someone else already has).

name: Qt Code Review
description: See how the Qt maintainers ensure their code is well-written.

name: Source Code
description: Browse the various source trees that comprise the Qt project.  Has mirrors at several GitHub organizations:

name: Mailing Lists
description: Mailing lists for users and developers of Qt alike.  Arguably the best place to communicate directly with Qt's maintainers.  Sees frequent activity.

name: Qt Forum
description: If e-mail's not your thing, then you might also consider getting help or sharing knowledge on the forums.

name: Qt Wiki
description: The premier source for user-contributed Qt knowledge.

name: IRC
description: For real-time chat with other Qt developers and users.  The most popular channels are on Freenode, and include #qt, #qt-quick, #qt-creator, and #qt-chat.

name: For a full list of Qt-related IRC channels, see here.
QtForum.org
description: Not to be confused with the official Qt forum.

name: Qt Creator
description: By no means does Qt lock you into its provided IDE, but its firm integration with the framework makes it a good sell.  Among other things, it provides a UI designer, modeling tools, a documentation browser, and great QML support if you're into that sort of thing.  There's also a plugin system, but third-party plugins are unfortunately scarce.

name: Qt Designer
description: If you'd rather just design the interfaces and let someone else hook them up to logic, the GUI designer is available as a separate application.

name: Qt Assistant
description: So is the documentation viewer, for that matter.

name: Qt Visual Studio Add-in
description: If you'd rather stick to Visual Studio, this add-in will let you do that.

name: Qt Linguist
description: Qt provides excellent internationalization/localization support, and this tool is very much responsible for it.  Write translatable strings in your code with special macros, and this tool will aggregate them all for you so you or your translator(s) can broaden your software's audience.

name: Qt Installer Framework
description: Nobody seems to talk about this, but Qt also provides a way to write an installer for your application.  Does not support creation of macOS disk images, app bundles, or Linux packages, so be mindful of that when considering your project's distribution.

name: macdeployqt
description: Generates macOS application bundles for Qt projects.

name: qmake
description: The bundled build system designed for Qt, though it can be used for non-Qt projects.

name: qbs
description: If QML is more your style, consider this alternative build system.

name: Emulator
description: Don't forget about Qt's mobile support!

name: CMake
description: General C++ build tool that happens to have great Qt support.

name: GammaRay
description: Powerful debugger and general inspection tool for Qt-built software.  Lets you inspect and manipulate the QObject hierarchy, view object properties, edit widgets at runtime, and far, far more.  A two-sentence blurb can't do it justice, seriously check it out.

name: moc-ng
description: Alternative implementation of moc that's binary-compatible with Qt's version.

name: Qt-Inspector
description: Inspection tool with similar goals to GammaRay, though much simpler.

name: SIP ðŸ“¦
description: Generates Python bindings for C or C++ libraries.  Has special support for Qt signals and slots, and was used to create PyQt.

name: linuxdeployqt
description: Lets you bundle your Qt based application as an AppDir or AppImage, making it possible to ship it to users of many desktop Linux distributions. Similar to the official windeployqt and macdeployqt tools but for Linux.

name: Python (via PyQt) ðŸ“¦
description: Arguably the most comprehensive and well-known binding of Qt to another language.

name: Python (via PySide) ðŸ“¦
description: Another binding for Python, which has been officially adopted by the Qt project.

name: Ring (via RingQt)
description: I've never heard of this language either, honestly.

name: Mono/.NET languages (via QtSharp)
description: Experimental wrapper for Qt that allows it to be used by .NET-based languages such as C#.  Young, but active.

name: mupdf-qt
description: Qt wrapper for the MuPDF PDF viewer.

name: neiasound
description: OpenAL wrapper designed for games, with stb_vorbis and libsndfile support.

name: PythonQt ðŸ“¦
description: Script your Qt applications with Python.  Not to be confused with PyQt or PySide.

name: QScintilla ðŸ“¦
description: Absurdly versatile and customizable text editor widget that provides syntax highlighting, code completion, code folding, recordable macros, and much more.  Built around Scintilla.  Created by the same company that developed PyQt.

name: QtAwesome
description: Add Font Awesome icons to your Qt application.  Other icon sets are supported, too.

name: QtLua ðŸ“¦
description: Use Lua as a scripting language for Qt-based software.

name: qtruby
description: Use Ruby as a scripting language within your application.

name: QuaZIP ðŸ“¦
description: Read from and write to ZIP archives.  Uses Minizip under the hood.

name: VLC-Qt
description: Wrapper for libvlc that lets you add a VLC-like media player to your application.

name: Communi
description: Cross-platform IRC framework.  We've got enough IRC clients out there already, but I suppose this could also be used to implement a chat function in your application (e.g. for community support).

name: cutelyst
description: Web framework that takes some ideas from Perl's Catalyst framework.

name: DiceParser
description: Dice Roller framework based on its own syntax.

name: DOtherSide
description: Binding for QML in C, primarily designed as an API for other languages to support QML.

name: glraw
description: Convert images from any Qt-supported format to OpenGL-format textures.  Useful for speeding up texture loading in graphics applications.

name: grantlee
description: Django-inspired text templating.

name: injeqt
description: Dependency injection for Qt.

name: KDE Frameworks  ðŸ“¦
description: Metric ass-ton of libraries for KDE, but many of them can be used with regular Qt applications as well.  Cross-platform, for the most part.

name: Marble ðŸ“¦
description: Virtual globe and map that can be used standalone or embedded within other applications.

name: qgexedit2
description: Embed a hex editor in your application.

name: qml-material
description: Material Design implemented in QML.

name: QNodeView
description: Widget that lets you create and edit nodes in a graph similar to the kind provided by Unreal Engine, Substance Designer, or PureData.

name: QSimpleUpdater
description: Let your application update itself.

name: qt-maybe
description: Fans of type theory will enjoy these sum and optional types.

name: qt-mustache
description: Render Mustache templates.

name: QtAV
description: Actively developed multimedia framework.

name: Qtilities
description: Powerful set of libraries that provide GUI, logging, testing, configuration, and project functionality (among other things) for your application.

name: QtitanChart
description: Chart generation framework.  Commercial.

name: QtitanRibbon
description: For fans of the ribbons that Microsoft uses in their software.  Commercial.

name: qtnotify
description: Notification framework.

name: QtTerminalWidget
description: Make your application capable of anything.

name: QtVerbalExpressions
description: Create regular expressions using natural English expressions.  Part of the VerbalExpressions project, which does the same thing for a wide variety of languages.

name: qtwebserver
description: If you need to write a web application server in Qt for some reason, this'll help you along.

name: QtXlsx
description: Read and write spreadsheets in Microsoft Excel format.

name: Qwt ðŸ“¦
description: Qt widgets designed for scientific and technical applications.

name: V-Play
description: Cross-platform 2D game engine and app framework that relies heavily on QML.  Has a lot of tools and resources, and may even deserve its own list.

name: verdigris
description: Experimental library to write Qt applications without using the moc.

name: #inqlude
description: The most well-known aggregation of Qt-centric libraries out there.  A package manager is also available here.

name: QtPods
description: Another Qt-centric package manager.  If you want to see the offerings without using QtPods, the full list is available here, and can be added to by submitting a pull request.

name: Linux-Apps.com
description: Despite the name, Linux-Apps.com aggregates a wide variety of Qt-based tools and libraries for both end-users and developers.

name: Stephan Binner's Ubuntu PPAs
description: Ubuntu users who are hesitant to install anything outside of their package managers can obtain any recent version of Qt from these repositories.  Instructions for adding them are found within.

name: Planet Qt
description: Official aggregation of first-party and third-party Qt-related blogs.

name: ICS
description: Qt-centric software consulting firm with a really neat blog.  Specializes in graphics applications.

name: Qt Tips and Tricks [1, 2]
description: Odds and ends that might be nice to keep in your back pocket.

name: Mastering Qt File Selectors
description: Sometimes you need different variations of the same asset, but you won't know which ones to load until runtime.  This class will decide for you.

name: Some Lesser Known Qt Tools and Commands [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]
description: You don't find hidden gems by staying on the beaten path.

name: Using Self-Signed Certificates in Qt Code
description: Trust nobody.

name: Integrating C++ with QML
description: Talk to your scripting language.  That's what it's there for.

name: Qt and OpenGL: Loading a 3D Model with Open Asset Import Library (Assimp) [1, 2]
description: Assimp supports a lot of different model types; these articles will help you support all of them.

name: What's new in Qt 5: QStandardPaths
description: This feature's been around for a few years, but it's still useful enough to warrant an entry on this list.

name: What's New in Qt 5.2: QCommandLineParser
description: Another oldie, but still a goodie.

name: Woboq
description: Another software consulting firm that also contributes code to Qt.  They seem to specialize in Qt's core architecture.

name: Moc myths debunked
description: The magic that Qt appears to rely in is really just a bunch of code generators.  This post will bring you up to speed on the reality of the moc, the most notable one.

name: How Qt Signals and Slots Work [1, 2, 3]
description: Qt's signals/slots system lets any object talk to any other object.  Understanding these three articles will help you take full advantage of the feature.

name: QMetaType knows your types
description: C++ isn't known for having good run-time type information, so Qt brings its own.

name: C++11 in Qt5
description: Stop writing C++ like it's 2003; learn how you can take advantage of recent C++ features in your Qt applications.

name: QStringLiteral explained
description: String literals are widely used in many applications; wouldn't it be nice if you could make them faster to access?

name: Nicer debug output in Qt using QT_MESSAGE_PATTERN
description: It's nice to be able to read your application's logs.

name: KDAB
description: Another consulting firm that specializes in Qt.

name: GammaRay: Taking a deep look into your Qt application
description: Talk about GammaRay and how it can help you dissect your Qt applications.  Talk given at QtCon 2016 by Volker Krause.

name: Multithreading with Qt
description: I want to make my application do more than once thing at once.  What could possibly go wrong?  Talk given at QtCon 2016 by Giuseppe D'Angelo.

name: Linux perf for Qt developers
description: How to make your Qt application faster, Linux-style.  Talk given at QtCon 2016 by Milian Wolff.

name: Qt5 C++ GUI Programming Cookbook, by Lee Zhi Eng
description: Overview of advanced GUI programming techniques for those familiar (but not satisfied) with the basics.  The source code used in the book is available for free.

name: Game Programming Using Qt: Beginner's Guide by Witold Wysota and Lorenz Haas
description: Good place to start learning how to program games with QML.

name: Application Development with Qt Creator
description: 2nd Edition, by Ray Rischpater - Beginner's guide to Qt, with a lot of focus on Qt Creator and its associated tools.

name: Qt 5 Blueprints, by Symeon Huang
description: Seems to be about the overall structure of a Qt project.

name: Mastering Qt 5, by Guillaume Lazar and Robin Penea
description: Not your daddy's Qt.  Tips and tricks for the experienced.  The source code used in the book is available for free.

name: PySide GUI Application Development
description: 2nd Edition, by Gopinath Jaganmohan and Venkateshwaran Loganathan - Imagine these other books, but in Python.

name: Qt5 Cadaques
description: Free book that focuses on QML, named for this town in northeastern Spain that the authors vacationed to once.

name: Autodesk Maya
description: 3D animation and design software that has been used to create visual effects for some of the most popular movies and TV shows of all time.

name: CMake
description: The closest thing to a standard C++ build system out there. The bundled GUI uses Qt.

name: CRYENGINE
description: But can it run Crysis?  Some auxillary tools use Qt.

name: Doxygen
description: The most popular documentation generator for C++, though it supports other languages as well.  The bundled GUI uses Qt.

name: Google Earth
description: The virtual globe.

name: KDE
description: One of the most popular desktop environments for Linux.

name: Malwarebytes
description: Your Windows desktop's personal bodyguard.

name: Parallels Desktop
description: Consumer-focused virtualization.

name: Qt Creator
description: Something something eating your own dog food. Listed in the official tools, but not listing it here doesn't feel right.

name: Rolisteam
description: Virtual tabletop for remote RoleÂ Playing Games.

name: RUBE
description: Level design tool for any game that uses the Box2D physics engine.

name: TeamSpeak
description: When gamers want to voice chat in a game that doesn't support it, they'll use this.

name: Telegram Desktop
description: Secure your conversations so well, you'll raise the blood pressure of potential eavesdroppers.  The desktop client uses Qt and is open source.

name: Tiled
description: Perhaps the world's most popular tilemap editor.  Suitable for level design in games.

name: VirtualBox ðŸ“¦
description: Virtualization software for x86/64 processors.  The bundled GUI uses Qt.

name: VLC ðŸ“¦
description: One of the most flexible open source video players in existence.

name: Vuo  â€” Realtime visual programming language for interactive media.
Wireshark ðŸ“¦
description: The most popular packet-sniffer out there.  You are going to use this for good and not evil, right?

name: Wolfram Mathematica
description: Programming language, symbolic calculator, and an engineer's best friend.

name: Yabause
description: Sega Saturn emulator.

name: Awesome C/C++
description: There's no reason you can't use C++ libraries that weren't designed for Qt.  Sometimes they might even suit your needs better than what Qt offers.

name: Awesome C
description: Same goes for C libraries; might wanna brush up on those RAII techniques while you're at it.

name: Awesome CMake
description: If you're not using qmake for your project, you're likely using CMake instead.

name: Awesome OpenGL
description: Qt is commonly used for graphics applications, even providing its own wrappers around OpenGL.
